messages.text: Would a bridge be the right place to implement some presolve features (in particular dependent constraint elimination), or should it be done at a lower level within the solver? I'm implementing a solver which will use a presolve to ensure that the input problem is well-formed, but I don't know what the most elegant place to implement said presolve is.

I'm implementing a solver which will use a presolve to ensure that the input problem is well-formed, but I don't know what the most elegant place to implement said presolve is.

messages.text: A meta solver like Dualization.jl would be very nice for a presolver. Bridges are not good for multi constraint transformations.

text.text:
A meta solver like Dualization.jl would be very nice for a presolver.
Bridges are not good for multi constraint transformations.

messages.text: Makes sense, that's a good approach.

text.text: Makes sense, that's a good approach.

messages.text: I've been thinking we need to formalize a way to write CVXPY-esque reductions: <https://www.cvxpy.org/api_reference/cvxpy.reductions.html>. We're starting to have a few like Dualization, a hypothetical presolver, <https://github.com/odow/MOO.jl>, there was also the issue of bridging `Complements` needing information of the variable bounds. The idea being a reduction wraps an inner optimizer, and implements a reduce/retrieve API. It would be nice to say, chain `Complementarity.Optimizer(Presolve.Optimizer(Gurobi.Optimizer()))`, to take a MPEC, reformulate with big-M or SOS, presolve, then solve with Gurobi.

text.text: I've been thinking we need to formalize a way to write CVXPY-esque reductions: <https://www.cvxpy.org/api_reference/cvxpy.reductions.html>. The idea being a reduction wraps an inner optimizer, and implements a reduce/retrieve API. It would be nice to say, chain `Complementarity.Optimizer(Presolve.Optimizer(Gurobi.Optimizer()))`, to take a MPEC, reformulate with big-M or SOS, presolve, then solve with Gurobi.

messages.text: Do we have any evolutionary "solvers" for MILP problems already?
What do you mean by "evolutionary solvers"?

elements.text: What do you mean by "evolutionary solvers"?

messages.text:
evolutionary algorithms have beaten Gurobi in the "quality of a solution after solve time t"-metric in some papers i came across, in addition they are really easy to parallelize even over high latency/low bandwidth links.
An evolutionary "solver" would be something that eats JuMP models and optimizes them until time limit or it gives up.
I don't really know what I'm talking about, but I strongly suspect that in the *vast* majority of cases, Gurobi wins with simplex/von-neumann

elements.text: I don't really know what I'm talking about, but I strongly suspect that in the
vast
majority of cases, Gurobi wins with simplex/von-neumann

messages.text: if you have a problem with a particularly nasty branch and bound, it might be worth trying something like that

elements.text: if you have a problem with a particularly nasty branch and bound, it might be worth trying something like that

messages.text: I am talking about problem where Gurobi is not fast enough to find the perfect solution it aims to find. It could very much be that enabled with an useful set of operations an evolutionary algorithm comes faster to 90% of optimum.
at the risk of saying something stupid because I'm missing the context, you do realize there are all sorts of options in Gurobi for returning inexact solutions right?

elements.text: at the risk of saying something stupid because I'm missing the context, you do realize there are all sorts of options in Gurobi for returning inexact solutions right?

messages.text: in particular your gap tolerance may be set too low

elements.text: in particular your gap tolerance may be set too low

messages.text: Gurobi may also be running evolutionary algorithms as heuristics for all we know.

elements.text: Gurobi may also be running evolutionary algorithms as heuristics for all we know.

messages.text: something I have learned in a few years of working a lot on MILP problems is that the performance characteristics of different problems can vary in really surprising ways.  Gurobi is so good at what it does because it is so good at handling so many different special cases in cleverly fast ways.  Finding something else that seems miraculously fast isn't super surprising, finding something that you can rely on to be that fast when you perturb your problem a bit is much harder

elements.text: something I have learned in a few years of working a lot on MILP problems is that the performance characteristics of different problems can vary in really surprising ways.  Gurobi is so good at what it does because it is so good at handling so many different special cases in cleverly fast ways.  Finding something else that seems miraculously fast isn't super surprising, finding something that you can rely on to be that fast when you perturb your problem a bit is much harder

messages.text:
I am aware, the problem is that i can't run Gurobi in production and run CBC instead (couldn't install SCIP on Fedora).
CBC produces not so good solutions in x hours, GLPK fails at well smaller problems, another solver i use via another AMPLwriter doesn't provide partial solutions (or atleast i haven't managed to concince him to do so.
I am just looking for other options i could try.

yeah, if you're running Cbc beating it is a lot easier, though even with Cbc (especially with cbc?) I'd recommend spending a good amount of time tweaking parameters, which unfortunately involves going through their abysmal (or in  some cases, non-existant) documentation

not necessarily... I'm just very skeptical about what "more traditional" options it'll be able to beat.  I personally wouldn't spend much time worrying about that until I've spent a good amount of time messing with Cbc and whatever other simplex/von-neumann solvers I could bring to bear on it

messages.text: Can you recommend a resource on cbc settings or where to get started

actually, I'm just contemplating this a little now as I drink my bourbon... if I had to make a bet, I'd say that a bunch of the commercial solvers use some sort of evolutionary algorithm as a vertex selection algorithm for simplex.  My guess would be that if you want to use an evolutionary algorithm on a MILP, it has to be one that knows the solutions live on the boundary to have any hope of being fast, and that pretty much puts it in the boat of being closely related to simplex

messages.text: Evolutionary programming is like 90% designing your gene (in this case designing it so it only permits feasible solutions or close to) and 10% on mutation and crossbreading

elements.text: Evolutionary programming is like 90% designing your gene (in this case designing it so it only permits feasible solutions or close to) and 10% on mutation and crossbreading

messages.text: So specialized EP solvers must be doing something clever with genome to make it mostly feasible.

elements.text: So specialized EP solvers must be doing something clever with genome to make it mostly feasible.

messages.text: But yeah that thing might be that my genome doesn't encode points it encodes instructions for how to do simplex to get points

elements.text: But yeah that thing might be that my genome doesn't encode points it encodes instructions for how to do simplex to get points

messages.text:
Here is my take:
evolutionary algorithms success is mostly depenend on the choice of good mutation primitives.
In my case it would be easy to provide some that help stay on feasible points. A Gurobi is probably not aware of those operations (or that the parameter space has a 8!-fold symmetry).
Knowledge like that might help find solutions.
In addition an ILP could run on an part of the genome as mutation to optimize a series of simpler problems while EA handles finding every attractor.

So anyway it sounds like you are not aware of any JuMP reafy evolutionary algorithms.
*sigh* looks for cbc docs
well gurobi (and probably others) is really good at finding special symmetries or whatever else that can make solutions really fast, that's what I'm saying

elements.text: well gurobi (and probably others) is really good at finding special symmetries or whatever else that can make solutions really fast, that's what I'm saying

messages.text:
If the question is “can I code a heuristic that outperforms Gurobi/CPLEX at finding good solutions early?”, then the answer is “Yes”. If you know something about your problem, it’ll be even easier.

Of course, MIP solvers do have heuristics, but they are general-purpose ones (not taylored to a particular problem) and typically fit within the B&B framework (eg diving heuristic, RINS, feasibility pump, etc). In addition, they try not only to find a good solution but to prove that it’s optimal. The latter is usually the hard part.

elements.text: If the question is “can I code a heuristic that outperforms Gurobi/CPLEX at finding good solutions early?”, then the answer is “Yes”. If you know something about your problem, it’ll be even easier.

Of course, MIP solvers do have heuristics, but they are general-purpose ones (not taylored to a particular problem) and typically fit within the B&B framework (eg diving heuristic, RINS, feasibility pump, etc). In addition, they try not only to find a good solution but to prove that it’s optimal. The latter is usually the hard part.

messages.text: Thanks for the hint with the callback but i am feeling abit overwhelmed already. I will look into it.
BTW does someone know why all the solver companies don't offer free solvers to non-profits, just academia?

It's a net positive giving to academia: you lock-in students to their software who then go out into industry and buy your code, and you get academics trying new algorithm tweaks to try and beat your code. Its also a prisoners dilemma: if one company does and the others don't, people quickly move to the one giving free academic licenses.

elements.text: It's a net positive giving to academia: you lock-in students to their software who then go out into industry and buy your code, and you get academics trying new algorithm tweaks to try and beat your code. Its also a prisoners dilemma: if one company does and the others don't, people quickly move to the one giving free academic licenses.

It would be in particular good to reduce these bills if i could turn on and off those machines to save on cloud compute billing.
The FICO community edition limits itself to problems CBC can handle fast.
I wouldn’t be surprised if solver companies were accommodating to non-profit as well.

messages.text:
Is there any reasonable explanation why the same ILP problem has two differently good optimas between Gurobi and CBC?
Ok it is just CBC being drunk. CBC gives a different answer (but saying "Optimal solution found.") while Gurobi always gives the same.

I did ran multi-threaded but there was no time-limit on CBC.
The run-to-run difference with CBC was >10% of the gurobi objective.

messages.text: One small question about the bridges I mentioned yesterday. I was able to simply use the FlipSignBridge for strictly greater than -> strictly less than constraints. Thanks for that. I currently run into a problem when I want to use GreaterThan inside an indicator constraint. The `_build_indicator_constraint` doesn't exist: ``` MethodError: no method matching _build_indicator_constraint(::JuMP.var"#_error#68"{Symbol}, ::VariableRef, ::BridgeableConstraint{ScalarConstraint{GenericAffExpr{Float64,VariableRef},ConstraintSolver.GreaterThan{Float64}},UnionAll}, ::Type{MathOptInterface.IndicatorSet{MathOptInterface.ACTIVATE_ON_ONE,S} where S<:MathOptInterface.AbstractScalarSet}) ``` I hoped it would call the indicator constraint with just the already briged ScalarConstraint as a type as  ``` _build_indicator_constraint(     _error::Function, variable::AbstractVariableRef,     constraint::ScalarConstraint, ::Type{MOI.IndicatorSet{A}}) ```  exists. How does this currently work with bridges?

text.text:
One small question about the bridges I mentioned yesterday. I was able to simply use the FlipSignBridge for strictly greater than -> strictly less than constraints. Thanks for that. I currently run into a problem when I want to use GreaterThan inside an indicator constraint. The `_build_indicator_constraint` doesn't exist:
```
MethodError: no method matching _build_indicator_constraint(::JuMP.var"#_error#68"{Symbol}, ::VariableRef, ::BridgeableConstraint{ScalarConstraint{GenericAffExpr{Float64,VariableRef},ConstraintSolver.GreaterThan{Float64}},UnionAll}, ::Type{MathOptInterface.IndicatorSet{MathOptInterface.ACTIVATE_ON_ONE,S} where S<:MathOptInterface.AbstractScalarSet})
```
I hoped it would call the indicator constraint with just the already briged ScalarConstraint as a type as 
```
_build_indicator_constraint(
    _error::Function, variable::AbstractVariableRef,
    constraint::ScalarConstraint, ::Type{MOI.IndicatorSet{A}})
``` 
exists. How does this currently work with bridges?

messages.text: I would like to build an MOI model with a collection of variables constrained to lie in Intervals. I would then like to modify some of the values of the upper/lower bounds in these intervals. Is there a straightforward way to do this using ``modify`` or something similar? Or do I need to use ``delete!`` and then re-add?

text.text: I would like to build an MOI model with a collection of variables constrained to lie in Intervals. I would then like to modify some of the values of the upper/lower bounds in these intervals. Is there a straightforward way to do this using ``modify`` or something similar? Or do I need to use ``delete!`` and then re-add?

messages.text: If the ser type is the same (Interval) you can just: MOI.set(model, MOI.ConstraintSet(), ci, MOI.Interval{Float64}(lb, ub))

text.text:
If the ser type is the same (Interval) you can just:
MOI.set(model, MOI.ConstraintSet(), ci, MOI.Interval{Float64}(lb, ub))

messages.text: ``` function _build_indicator_constraint(     _error::Function, variable::AbstractVariableRef,     constraint::BridgeableConstraint, I::Type{MOI.IndicatorSet{A}}) where A     return BridgeableConstraint(         _build_indicator_constraint(_error, variable, constraint.constraint, I),         constraint.bidge_type     ) end ```
It would be functionally the same, though a bit uglier. Still trying to work out how much I care about that, though.

messages.text: Hi there! I am just starting with MOI and JuMP integration for my solver. I am a bit lost, but I will do my best. FYI, I am developing a CBLS (Constraint-Based Local Search) solver framework called LocalSearchSolvers.jl. The first beta is out (package is officially registered), but MOI and JuMP integration is one of the most important features before a v1.0 I have already some questions (and I will probably have more ...). Please be gentle ^^

text.text:
Hi there! I am just starting with MOI and JuMP integration for my solver. I am a bit lost, but I will do my best. FYI, I am developing a CBLS (Constraint-Based Local Search) solver framework called LocalSearchSolvers.jl. The first beta is out (package is officially registered), but MOI and JuMP integration is one of the most important features before a v1.0
I have already some questions (and I will probably have more ...). Please be gentle ^^

messages.text: My first big question is that most (actually all at the moment) of  my constraints are simply predicates applied to a set of variables. Variables can be anything (continuous, discrete, any T <: Number). Objective(s) are not mandatory (there is SAT and OPT models). So I am trying to understand what are the minimum things I need to define for my Optimizer directly (without using submodules such as Bridges for the moment)

text.text: My first big question is that most (actually all at the moment) of  my constraints are simply predicates applied to a set of variables. Variables can be anything (continuous, discrete, any T <: Number). Objective(s) are not mandatory (there is SAT and OPT models). So I am trying to understand what are the minimum things I need to define for my Optimizer directly (without using submodules such as Bridges for the moment)

messages.text: As far as I know JuMP only supports `T = Float64` but MOI supports more.

text.text: As far as I know JuMP only supports `T = Float64` but MOI supports more.

messages.text: For the methods it's quite helpful to checkout other repositories as well as the documentation. That should mention how variables and constraints are defined

text.text: For the methods it's quite helpful to checkout other repositories as well as the documentation. That should mention how variables and constraints are defined

messages.text: I actually am looking at yours at the moment :p But I have to many things to integrate at the same type, so I am trying to do divide and conquer the whole thing. So I am looking for which steps I should take first. Maybe make a very short test file for simple problem (such as sudoku) and implement MOI stuff until it works out. Then add optional things.

text.text:
I actually am looking at yours at the moment :p
But I have to many things to integrate at the same type, so I am trying to do divide and conquer the whole thing. So I am looking for which steps I should take first. Maybe make a very short test file for simple problem (such as sudoku) and implement MOI stuff until it works out. Then add optional things.

messages.text: You need: - `mutable struct Optimizer <: MOI.AbstractOptimizer` - `function Optimizer()` which returns the optimizer  I think with those two you have the option to write `m = Model(MySolver.Optimizer)` already. - then you can have a look at my MOI_wrapper/variables.jl` to see methods for `supports_constraint` and `MOI.SingleVariable` (SVF)  - you need `add_variable` as well as something like `function MOI.add_constraint(model::Optimizer, v::SVF, lt::MOI.LessThan{T}) where {T<:Real}` for bounded variables. Something very similar for constraints and objectives. Testing all this might be easier with writing MOI models first instead of using JuMP. Often you'll be guided into the right direction by error messages ;)

text.text:
You need:
- `mutable struct Optimizer <: MOI.AbstractOptimizer`
- `function Optimizer()` which returns the optimizer 
I think with those two you have the option to write `m = Model(MySolver.Optimizer)` already.
- then you can have a look at my MOI_wrapper/variables.jl` to see methods for `supports_constraint` and `MOI.SingleVariable` (SVF) 
- you need `add_variable` as well as something like `function MOI.add_constraint(model::Optimizer, v::SVF, lt::MOI.LessThan{T}) where {T<:Real}` for bounded variables.
Something very similar for constraints and objectives.
Testing all this might be easier with writing MOI models first instead of using JuMP. Often you'll be guided into the right direction by error messages ;)

messages.text: For Sudoku you need integer variables of course but it's a similar structure.

text.text: For Sudoku you need integer variables of course but it's a similar structure.

messages.text: Here was my (unhelpful) suggestion for the minimum things you need to define: <https://github.com/jump-dev/MathOptInterface.jl/issues/662#issuecomment-460658296>. I would pick a similar solver as inspiration, and implement stuff until it works (e.g., write some small MOI examples, and keep implementing the missing method errors).
